docs.abstract: Michel Rocard, Prime Min of France from 1988 to 1991 whose Socialist reforms had lasting influence, dies at age 85.

headline.main: Michel Rocard, Former Prime Minister of France, Dies at 85

docs.snippet: OLICK--Arthur, died on July 2 in Bethesda, Maryland of multiple sclerosis (M.S.). He was 85. He will be remembered as a loving husband, devoted father, grandfather, and brother, and an attorney with few equals. Rising from modest beginnings in the...
docs.lead_paragraph:
OLICK--Arthur,

died on July 2 in Bethesda, Maryland of multiple sclerosis (M.S.). He was 85. He will be remembered as a loving husband, devoted father, grandfather, and brother, and an attorney with few equals. Rising from modest beginnings in the Bronx in New York City, he forged a legal career of unusual accomplishment that included study at Yale University (B.A. 1952; J.D. 1955), public service in the U.S. Army (1956-57) and the U.S. Attorney's office for the Southern District of New York (1962-68), and private practice at several Manhattan law firms, most notably Anderson, Kill & Olick from which he retired. Through the course of a wide-ranging career he represented both local municipalities and prominent cultural figures, became one of the nation's leading experts on insurance coverage litigation, and was known to many as a lawyer's lawyer, as evidenced by his representation of law firms in high-profile bankruptcy proceedings. Arthur Seymour Olick was born on June 15, 1931 to Anita Babsky and Jacob (Jack) Olick, both first generation Americans born in New York City. Jack was a technical writer who was also what is now called an "early adopter" of new technologies, thanks to which Arthur was one of only a handful of Americans who learned of the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941 via television. He graduated from Evander Childs High School at age 16 before going on to study political science at Yale where he graduated magna cum laude and was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. He also excelled at Yale Law School where he was a moot court champion. It was at Yale where Arthur met and, in 1954, married Selma Ada Kaufman of New Haven. They were married for 62 years, during which Selma was Art's constant companion, mother to the couple's two children, Robert (born 1957) and Karen (born 1961), and, in later years as his M.S. progressed, Art's caregiver and advocate. Upon relocating to New York following his Army service, Art entered private practice for several years before joining the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York under Robert Morgenthau, where he worked for six years (1962-68), the last three as Chief of the Civil Division. He returned to private practice as a partner at several law firms before joining the firm of Gene Anderson, his former colleague at the U.S. Attorney's Office. Together, Anderson, Olick, and other attorneys at the firm became nationally recognized for their innovative litigation strategies on behalf of insurance policyholders seeking coverage for personal injuries and other damages related to exposure to asbestos. He also served as managing partner of the firm, lectured frequently on trial practice, partnerships, product liability, and business bankruptcy, and represented Zsa Zsa Gabor, Peter Max, Don McLean, Meatloaf, and Gloria Swanson on various commercial matters. Throughout his years of private practice, however, Arthur was continually inspired by the call of public service. He was very active in civic affairs in Westchester County where the family lived for most of the 1960s, 70s, and 80s, serving as attorney for several local townships. It was in this capacity that he engaged in a series of court cases to deny tax-exempt status under state and local laws for Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church. In one case, Arthur won a court order to cross-examine Moon, leading the Unification Church to quickly settle. In addition, he served as president of the Greenburg Central Seven School District, leading the implementation of a controversial busing program in the 1970s. He and Selma were also founding members of Bet Am Shalom, a Reconstructionist temple in White Plains. The family built a weekend home in Putnam Valley where they spent many weekends with family and friends, and where, true to his deep sense of patriotism, Art raised and lowered the American flag on national holidays to recorded military music. In retirement, Art and Selma spent part of the year in Florida and as much time as possible every year enjoying theater, opera, and their grandchildren. Arthur was defined by a lifelong drive to learn, to lead, and to serve. He pursued great passions with great energy, led nearly every institution in which he served, set high standards and expectations for colleagues and his family members alike, and, by any measure, achieved the success associated with the American Dream in which he so fervently believed. Arthur is survived by his children Robert (Manlius, NY) and Karen (Washington, DC), her husband John Gibson, and five grandchildren, Joshua, Sarah, Rachel, Stephen, and Grant, and his brothers Phillip (New York City) and David (San Francisco). His wife Selma preceded him in death earlier this year. Services Thursday, July 7th, at 11am at Riverside Chapel, Manhattan. Family will be receiving at the Yale Club at 50 Vanderbilt Avenue on Thursday from 5-8pm. Donations may be made in Arthur's name to the Multiple Sclerosis Society.

docs.snippet: WIESEL--Elie. The Zamir Choral Foundation joins the world in mourning the passing of Elie Wiesel, our conscience, transmitter of memory, and a giant among men whose voice and legacy will remain an inspiration for generations to come. A consummate ...
docs.lead_paragraph:
WIESEL--Elie.

The Zamir Choral Foundation joins the world in mourning the passing of Elie Wiesel, our conscience, transmitter of memory, and a giant among men whose voice and legacy will remain an inspiration for generations to come. A consummate teacher and scholar, and a master of Hasidic song, our Honorary Chairman for a quarter of a century combined his love of music with his profound understanding of text, bringing both to the Heavenly spheres. We are honored to share and continue to be motivated by his deep commitment to moral courage, respect for all humanity, love of Israel and Jerusalem, and the eternity of the Jewish People. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Marion, son Elisha (Lynn), grandchildren and the entire family. May his memory, as was his life, be a blessing to us all. Matthew Lazar, Founder and Director Steven C. Lorch, President Zamir Choral Foundation

docs.snippet: WIESEL--Elie. S'iz gefaln a demb - we have lost a great man. The League for Yiddish mourns the passing of Eliezer Wiesel, our honorary Board member. His first book, "Un di velt hot geshvign", was published in his native Yiddish, and its adaptation...
docs.lead_paragraph:
WIESEL--Elie.

S'iz gefaln a demb - we have lost a great man. The League for Yiddish mourns the passing of Eliezer Wiesel, our honorary Board member. His first book, "Un di velt hot geshvign", was published in his native Yiddish, and its adaptation into the volume "Night" introduced him to the wider world. May his support for our cause - Yiddish - inspire others. Sheva Zucker, Exec. Dir., and Gitl Schaechter- Viswanath, Chair leagueforyiddish.org

docs.snippet: WIESEL--Elie. American Jewish Heritage/ Dialogue Forum deeply mourns the immense loss of our Honorary Chairman, mentor, teacher, friend. Across more than four decades he strongly supported with encouragement advice and help our work of fighting ha...
docs.lead_paragraph:
WIESEL--Elie.

American Jewish Heritage/ Dialogue Forum deeply mourns the immense loss of our Honorary Chairman, mentor, teacher, friend. Across more than four decades he strongly supported with encouragement advice and help our work of fighting hatred, promoting Judaism, building a better world. We who survive him shall always continue the legacy he handed over to us. Rabbi Perry Berkowitz Rabbi Leah Berkowitz

docs.snippet: RUBEN--Lawrence. September 28, 1926 - July 3, 2016. Cherished husband of Jan Ruben and the late Selma Ruben. Beloved father of Richard, Lenore, and Shelly and father-in-law of Howard Kivell and Amy Ruben. Adored grandfather of Tamara, Danielle, Wi...
docs.lead_paragraph:
RUBEN--Lawrence.

September 28, 1926 - July 3, 2016. Cherished husband of Jan Ruben and the late Selma Ruben. Beloved father of Richard, Lenore, and Shelly and father-in-law of Howard Kivell and Amy Ruben. Adored grandfather of Tamara, Danielle, William, Andrew, Melissa, Robert, James, Allison and Caroline, and great-grandfather of Blake, Sasha, Jonah, and Owen. As Chairman of Ruben Companies, he helped shape the skyline of New York City. Life Overseer of Weill Cornell Medicine, and Honorary Overseer of Cardozo School of Law. His love and passion for his family, his work, and his city will be missed. Funeral services will be Tuesday, July 5, 12pm, at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Donations in his memory may be made to Weill Cornell Medicine.

docs.snippet: WIESEL--Elie. The World Jewish Congress mourns the passing of one of the preeminent Jewish thinkers, human rights activists, authors, teachers, and moral authorities of our age, Nobel Peace Prize laureate Elie Wiesel. After surviving the horrors o...
docs.lead_paragraph:
WIESEL--Elie.

The World Jewish Congress mourns the passing of one of the preeminent Jewish thinkers, human rights activists, authors, teachers, and moral authorities of our age, Nobel Peace Prize laureate Elie Wiesel. After surviving the horrors of Auschwitz and Buchenwald, Elie Wiesel taught the world the true meaning of remembrance and dedicated himself to fighting evil, bigotry and xenophobia in all its forms. More than anyone else, he ensured that the victims of the Shoah would be remembered, not only for how they were murdered, but for who they were and how they lived. We are proud to have counted him among the dearest friends of the World Jewish Congress, and that we were privileged to honor him with the Guardian of Jerusalem Prize in 2010, and with our highest honor, the Theodor Herzl Award, in 2013. We extend our deepest condolences and those of our more than 100 affiliated Jewish communities across the globe to his wife and life partner Marion, his cherished son Elisha, daughter-in-law Lynn, stepdaughter Jennifer, his beloved grandchildren, and his entire family. May his memory be a blessing and an eternal inspiration to us all. Ronald S. Lauder, President David de Rothschild, Chairman, Governing Board Chella Safra, Treasurer Robert Singer, CEO
